title: Afloat and Ashore: A Sea Tale

quoteFirst: A little vanity there may have been in this, for however badly off we are ourselves, we are not displeased to see some people still worse off, and are gratified in laying them under some miserable obligation. Left Sebhah
quoteLast: , and after three hours' ride came in view of a forest of date-palms. This wood of palms is out of the line of route, and extends from Sebhah to Timhanah, a day's journey.
title: Travels in the Great Desert of Sahara, in the Years of 1845 and 1846

quoteFirst: But even then the figure of the old man often started before me, and a sense of uneasiness about George made a strong undercurrent to my drifting dreams. I was awakened at
quoteTime: about eight o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: by the engineer, who told me one of the old man's sons had been picked up and was now on board.
title: Selected Stories of Bret Harte
author: Harte, Bret, 1836-1902

quoteFirst: an apparently strong woman was once offered a night job when she was hard up, and thought that it would be a "lark" to take it. She went in
quoteLast: on Friday and worked on with intervals for meals till 3 p.m. on Saturday, being paid piece rates for the day hours and 6_s._ for the work between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. She was utterly done up in consequence of this work and lost more money next week than she made by the whole job.
title: Women in the Printing Trades: A Sociological Study.
author: MacDonald, James Ramsay, 1866-1937 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Our stores consisted of three bags of pemmican, seventy reindeer tongues, one half-hundred weight of flour, some tea, chocolate, and sugar, and a little alcohol and oil for fuel. At first the weather was far from favourable for travelling, as there was a gale of wind with snow, but
quoteLast: the sky cleared up, and the day became as fine as could have been wished. The sun shone forth with great brightness, surrounded by a halo of the most brilliant colours, with four parhelia that rivalled the sun himself.
title: Narrative of an Expedition to the Shores of the Arctic Sea in 1846 and 1847
author: Rae, John, 1813-1893

quoteLast: : Napoleon had risen at six, and went on the poop, whence he surveyed the coast and anchorage. I remained by his side to give the explanations he required."--_Las Cases_, tom. i., p. 41.
title: Life of Napoleon Bonaparte, Volume V.
author: Scott, Walter, 1771-1832
